header.title: The New Writings of Rav Ashlag: Article on World Peace Part 13

central_thesis: Humanity's inherent 'Unique Individuality', while divinely sourced, becomes the root of all conflict and destruction when corrupted by egoism, manifesting as a 'desire to receive for oneself' rather than 'sharing with others'. Achieving world peace necessitates transforming this egoistic receiving into altruistic sharing, thereby aligning human nature with the Creator's attribute of giving.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Qualities of Mercy, Truth, Righteousness and Peace Fight One Another
structure_content.summary: This section introduces the foundational problem: key human virtues like Mercy, Truth, Righteousness, and Peace do not coexist harmoniously but rather 'lock horns' and fight, both within individuals and between societal groups. This internal and external conflict stems from a deeper, unresolved issue that common sense cannot reconcile.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Root of All the Contradictions in the World
structure_content.summary: Identifies the 'Unique Individuality' present in every person as the ultimate source of all confusion and contradiction. This individuality is presented as having a beautiful, exalted, and grand purpose, being directly extended from the Creator, the 'Individual of the world'.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Corruption of Unique Individuality by Egoism
structure_content.summary: Explains that when 'Unique Individuality' becomes 'narrow egoism', its inherent purpose is perverted into an action of destruction and ruin. This egoism is universal, and all human disagreements (driven by desires, governance, or honor) are merely different manifestations of this fundamental drive to exploit others for personal benefit, often leading to the destruction of others for self-advantage.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Primacy of Desire and the Magnification of Individuality
structure_content.summary: Asserts that the 'desire to receive' is the fundamental root of the mind, overriding intellectual justifications. It also posits that the greater and more excellent a person is, the more potent their 'Unique Individuality' is, implying that its potential for both good and destructive manifestation increases with inherent greatness.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Paradox of Unique Individuality: Source of Construction or Destruction?
structure_content.summary: Presents the core paradox: how can 'Unique Individuality', which originates from the Creator (the source of all construction and glory), manifest among humans in such a distorted and destructive fashion, becoming the progenitor of all ruin? This question highlights the central tension explored in the article.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Two Sides of the Coin of Unique Individuality
structure_content.summary: Elaborates on the dual nature of Unique Individuality. The 'exalted side', representing its affinity with the Creator, operates solely through 'sharing with others' because the Creator lacks nothing. Conversely, the 'lower, second aspect', as it operates practically within humans, functions entirely as 'receiving for oneself' (e.g., ambition for wealth or honor). These two aspects are fundamentally opposed and obstruct each other, explaining the internal and external conflicts.

key_concepts.definition: An inherent quality within each person, directly extended from the Creator ('Individual of the world'). It is intrinsically beautiful and exalted, but when corrupted by egoism, it becomes the root of all contradictions and conflicts. Its ultimate potential lies in 'sharing with others'.

The distorted manifestation of 'Unique Individuality', characterized by the 'desire to receive for oneself' at the expense of others. It is the root cause of destruction, ruin, and all disagreements among humanity, leading individuals to exploit others for personal gain.

The fundamental driving force within humans, which, when egoistic, prioritizes personal benefit and leads to conflict and destruction. The text distinguishes this egoistic reception from the Creator's nature of sharing.

The ideal, exalted mode of operation for 'Unique Individuality', reflecting the Creator's nature. It represents the correction of egoism and the path to harmony and world peace, as opposed to 'receiving for oneself'.

key_concepts.term: Qualities of Mercy, Truth, Righteousness, and Peace
key_concepts.definition: Fundamental virtues that, in an uncorrected state of 'Unique Individuality' driven by egoism, become conflicting forces within individuals and society, preventing harmony and cooperation.

practical_system.description: While this specific excerpt focuses on diagnosing the problem, it lays the groundwork for a practical system centered on the transformation of consciousness. The 'system' implied is the rectification of 'Unique Individuality' from its egoistic 'receiving for oneself' mode to its altruistic 'sharing with others' mode. This transformation is presented as the prerequisite for resolving all conflicts and achieving world peace. The text doesn't explicitly detail operative rituals or tools within these pages but strongly implies that the path to peace is an internal, spiritual one, necessitating a shift in one's fundamental intention and mode of interaction with the world.

relevant_quotes.text: The qualities of Mercy, Truth, Righteousness and Peace Fight One Another
Thus you see, how these qualities within us lock horns and fight with each other, not only between one sect of society and another, but also within each individual as well.

And the truth is, that the root of all this great confusion that prevails in us is no other than the Unique Individuality that we mentioned earlier, which is present in each and every one of us, to a lesser or greater degree.
Still, because it became our narrow egoism, its action has become that of destruction and ruin.

But the equal aspect all the people of the world share with each other is that each one of us is ready to take advantage of all the other people in the world for his own personal benefit, using every possible means at his disposal, not taking into account that in so doing he is going to benefit himself on the basis of the destruction of the other.
The desire to receive is the root of the mind; the mind is not the root of the desire.

That question is valid and demands an answer: how is it that it [the principle of Unique Individuality] manifests among us in such a distorted fashion, having become the root cause and progenitor of all the destroyers and ruin mongers of the world?

Indeed, there are two sides to the coin of the said Unique Individuality. Because if we examine it from the point of view of one side, the exalted side, which means from the aspect of it's affinity with the Individual of this world, that aspect only operates through a mode which we call 'sharing with others.'... But looking at the other side of the same coin... it operates only when taking the form of 'receiving for oneself.'

critical_analysis.relevance: This article is a foundational text within the Kabbalistic tradition, particularly Rav Ashlag's lineage, providing a deep metaphysical diagnosis of human conflict. It situates the problem not in external factors, but in a fundamental internal distortion of a divinely imbued human quality. By identifying 'Unique Individuality' and its egoistic corruption as the root cause, it offers a spiritual framework for understanding global and personal strife. It is highly relevant for practitioners seeking to understand the Kabbalistic path of 'Tikkun' (correction), which is predicated on transforming the 'desire to receive for oneself' into 'receiving in order to give' or 'sharing'. The text sets the stage for a practical system aimed at achieving world peace through individual inner work, rather than mere political or social restructuring.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of students and practitioners of Kabbalah, particularly those engaged in the teachings of Rav Ashlag and the Kabbalah Centre. It also appeals to individuals interested in esoteric philosophy, spiritual ethics, and the metaphysical roots of human behavior and conflict. An understanding of basic Kabbalistic concepts and terminology (e.g., 'Creator,' 'desire to receive') would be beneficial for full comprehension.
